factoid: Pierre looked at his friend.
Pierre noticed that the friend did not like the conversation.
Pierre gave no reply.
Pierre asked, "When are you starting?"
Lise said, "Oh, don’t speak of his going, don’t! I won’t hear it spoken of."
Lise spoke in a petulantly playful tone.
Lise had spoken to Hippolyte in the drawing room in that tone.
The tone was ill-suited to the family circle of which Pierre was almost a member.
Pierre was almost a member of the family circle.
Lise remembered that all these delightful associations must be broken off.
Lise whispered, "I’m afraid, I’m afraid!"
A shudder ran down Lise's back.
Prince Andrew looked at Lise as if surprised to notice that someone besides Pierre and himself was in the room.
Prince Andrew addressed Lise in a tone of frigid politeness.
Prince Andrew asked Lise, "What is it you are afraid of, Lise? I don’t understand."
Lise said, "There, what egotists men all are: all, all egotists!"
Lise said, "Just for a whim of his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone in the country."
Prince Andrew said, "With my father and sister, remember."
Lise said, "Alone all the same, without my friends. And he expects me not to be afraid."
Lise's tone was querulous.
Lise's lip was drawn up.
Lise's expression was animal, squirrel-like.
Lise paused as if she felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre.
Lise felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre.
Prince Andrew said, "I still can’t understand what you are afraid of," slowly, not taking his eyes off Lise.
Lise blushed.
Lise raised her arms with a gesture of despair.
Lise said, "No, Andrew, I must say you have changed. Oh, how you have..."
Prince Andrew said, "Your doctor tells you to go to bed earlier."
Prince Andrew said, "You had better go."
Lise said nothing.
Lise's short downy lip quivered.
Prince Andrew rose.
Prince Andrew shrugged his shoulders.
Prince Andrew walked about the room.
Pierre looked over his spectacles with naive surprise.
Pierre looked at himself and at Lise.
Pierre moved as if about to rise too.
Pierre changed his mind.
Lise exclaimed, "Why should I mind Monsieur Pierre being here?"
Lise said, "I have long wanted to ask you, Andrew, why you have changed so to me?"
Lise asked, "What have I done to you?"
Lise said, "You are going to the war and have no pity for me."
Lise asked, "Why is it?"
Prince Andrew said, "Lise!"
Lise said, "You treat me like an invalid or a child."
Lise said, "I see it all!"
Lise asked, "Did you behave like that six months ago?"
Prince Andrew said, "Lise, I beg you to desist."
Pierre rose.
Pierre approached Lise.
Pierre seemed unable to bear the sight of tears.
Pierre was ready to cry himself.

Prince Andrew said, "Calm yourself, Princess! It seems so to you because… I assure you I myself have experienced … and so ... because ... No, excuse me! An outsider is out of place here… No, don’t distress yourself… Good‑by!"
Prince Andrew caught Pierre by the hand.
Prince Andrew said, "No, wait, Pierre! The princess is too kind to wish to deprive me of the pleasure of spending the evening with you."
Lise muttered, "No, he thinks only of himself."
Prince Andrew said, "Lise!" dryly, raising his voice to the pitch indicating that patience is exhausted.
Lise's angry, squirrel-like expression changed into a winning and piteous look of fear.
Lise's beautiful eyes glanced askance at Prince Andrew's face.
Lise assumed the timid, deprecating expression of a dog when it rapidly but feebly wags its drooping tail.
Lise muttered, "Mon Dieu, mon Dieu!"
Lise lifted her dress with one hand.
Lise went up to Prince Andrew and kissed him on the forehead.
Prince Andrew said, "Good night, Lise," and kissed Lise's hand.
